property.name: _windowProperties
property.value: {bounds={249, 111, 1191, 632}, maximized=false}

property.name: text
property.value: Examples of the four types of SPARQL queries that return responses from a semantic repository.

property.name: text
property.value: For this model to work, you must first start an instance of a semantic repository (with data) named "FirstRepo" on localhost port 7200. For example, try graphDB http://graphdb.ontotext.com/ with the sample dataset that comes with the download.

entity.name: StringConst

property.name: value
property.value: CONSTRUCT {?s ?p ?o} WHERE {?s ?p ?o} LIMIT 10

entity.doc: Create a constant sequence with a string value.

entity.name: StringConst2

property.name: value
property.value: SELECT * WHERE {?s ?p ?o} LIMIT 10

entity.doc: Create a constant sequence with a string value.

entity.name: StringConst3

property.name: value
property.value: DESCRIBE ?x WHERE { ?x ?p ?o } LIMIT 10

entity.doc: Create a constant sequence with a string value.

entity.name: StringConst4

property.name: value
property.value: ASK {?s ?p ?o}

entity.doc: Create a constant sequence with a string value.

property.name: script
note
property.value: NOTE: To see the script, invoke Open Actor

property.name: description
property.value:
Perform a SPARQL query on a semantic repository such as GraphDB.

SPARQL is a W3C standard for querying semantic repositories, playing an analogous role to SQL with respect to relational databases. Semantic repositories fall within the domain of knowledge representation in AI and typically are implemented as a triplestore: entries in the repository have the form "subject", "predicate", "object" eg. "An Apple" "IsA" "Fruit"

An example SPARQL query to get a list of up to 100 triples in the repository:

select * where { ?s ?p ?o . } limit 100

Documentation for SPARQL and the SPARQL Protocol can be found at https://www.w3.org/TR/rdf-sparql-query/

Information on GraphDB can be found at http://graphdb.ontotext.com/

SPARQL is also a protocol for communicating with RDF databases Upon receiving a query input, this accessor performs an http GET to the specified server and port with the querystring "query" set to the query input. The JSON response from the semantic repository (if any) is sent to the response output. Depending on the query type, the response will be JSON

This accessor does not block waiting for the response, but if any additional query input is received before a pending request has received a response or timed out, then the new request will be queued and sent out only after the pending request has completed. This strategy ensures that outputs are produced in the same order as the input requests.

property.name: author
property.value: Matt Weber

property.name: version
property.value: $$Id: SemanticRepository.js 1725 2017-05-19 22:59:11Z cxh $$

property.name: query (port)
property.value: The SPARQL query to be sent to the semantic repository. Types of queries yielding a response are: SELECT, CONSTRUCT, ASK, and DESCRIBE

property.name: response (port)
property.value: An object containing the raw response from the service conforming to the SPARQL protocol. If the query type was SELECT or ASK the response will be JSON "sparql-results". If the query type was CONSTRUCT or DESCRIBE the response will be JSON "rdf".

property.name: host (parameter)
property.value: The URL for the semantic repository.

property.name: port (parameter)
property.value: The port for the semantic repository.

property.name: repositoryName (parameter)
property.value: The name of the particular repository on the host.

property.name: timeout (parameter)
property.value: The amount of time (in milliseconds) to wait for a response before triggering a null response and an error. This defaults to 20000.

property.name: _windowProperties
property.value: {bounds={410, 611, 499, 208}, maximized=false}

property.name: script
note
property.value: NOTE: To see the script, invoke Open Actor

property.name: description
property.value: Display data using util.inspect() to render a more human-readable form. Any data accepted by util.inspect() can be displayed. The title may be used by the host to label the output in some way, either by labeling a display window or prepending the printed text with the title. The resulting text is passed through to the output in case a model wishes to ensure that the image has been displayed before something else happens or the model wishes to use the rendered text in some way.

property.name: author
property.value: Edward A. Lee

property.name: input (port)
property.value: The text to display.

property.name: output (port)
property.value: The text to display.
